Thanks for the heads up. It has been a very long time since I have 
messed =
with any type of AI coding (over a decade) so it will pretty 
much be like =
starting over for me. The last program I even messed 
with was written in a=
ssembly for DOS called BUGZ. It was a 
predator/prey style AI, worked prett=
y good and supported up to 2000 
insects. It still even works in the Window=
s console.

One thing about the Windows NEAT implementation is that it is a=
 bit 
unstable, most likely due to it running out of memory. As long as I 
=
keep the time length at 1000 or below, it usually won't crash.

In your opi=
nion would building a FSM handler be simply make it create 
a predefined sc=
ript once a paticular node tree becomes stable after a 
set amount of gener=
ations?

Thanks,
LS

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanl=
ey@...> wrote:
>
> Lancer, thanks for the contribution.
> 
> Several years =
ago, Prof. Stephanie Forrest at the University of New
> Mexico told me abou=
t a class assignment she had given in which her
> students evolved FSMs wit=
h their own NEAT implementations.  The
> results were apparently mixed, wit=
h some seeming to work and some 
not
> working at all.  However, she had no=
t required the students to
> implement speciation because of time constrain=
ts in the semester, so
> these were NEAT implementations without species.  =
Based on that fact
> that some seemed to work okay anyway, I'd guess that w=
ith a full
> implementation of NEAT, it might work pretty well.
> 
> Of cou=
rse, there are some new issues that come up.  For example, 
each
> node has=
 a different identity.  Also, maybe more interesting, it is
> not clear wha=
t topology should begin evolution in the initial
> population (or if perhap=
s the initial population should contain a
> variety of simple topologies).
=
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "lancersolurus" <gaming@> wrote:=

> >
> > I uploaded a version of Mat's NEAT program that will compile 
unde=
r

(a=
 no-

En=
joy...
